Description: THE ACCS WILL COLLECT NON-NATIVE AND NATIVE PLANT DATA FROM BLM-MANAGED LANDS WITHIN THE ANCHORAGE DISTRICT OFFICE BOUNDARIES, SPECIFICALLY FOCUSED ON THE MAJOR CHECKPOINTS WEST OF THE ALASKA RANGE NEAR BLM-MANAGED LANDS ALONG THE HISTORIC IDITAROD TRAIL. THIS WILL BE REASSESSING THE PRESENCE AND ABSENCE OF NON-NATIVE PLANTS AT THE CHECKPOINTS. THE ACCS PERFORMED THE FIRST INVENTORY OF THE TRAIL IN 2009.ACCS WILL ORGANIZE, REVIEW AND DELIVER NON-NATIVE PLANT SPECIES DATA TO THE ALASKA EXOTIC PLANTS INFORMATION CLEARINGHOUSE (AKEPIC), THE STATEWIDE REPOSITORY FOR DATA ON NON-NATIVE PLANTS MANAGED BY ACCS. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE A MORE ROBUST DATASET OF NON-NATIVE PLANT INFESTATIONS FOR HIGHER TRAFFIC CHECKPOINTS ALONG THE IDITAROD TRAIL. AN ANALYSIS OF PAST SURVEY DATA WILL ALLOW MANAGERS TO UNDERSTAND WHAT SPECIES HAVE RECENTLY BEEN INTRODUCED AS WELL AS WHICH SPECIES CONTINUE TO PROLIFERATE IN REMOTE LOCATIONS OFF OF THE ROAD SYSTEM. BLM CAN TARGET EDUCATIONAL ACTIVITIES AND POSSIBLE ERADICATION EFFORTS BASED ON WHERE ACTIONS WILL HAVE THE MOST BENEFICIAL EFFECT.

THIS PROJECTS AIMS TO ENHANCE SAGE-GROUSE HABITAT ACROSS JURISDICTION BOUNDARIES IN THE BAKER PRIORITY AREA OF CONSERVATION (PAC) IN CONJUNCTION WITH ONGOING PROJECTS FUNDED BY THE OREGON WATERSHED ENHANCEMENT BOARD (OWEB), OREGON STATE WEED BOARD (OSWB), AND THE NATURAL RESOURCES CONSERVATION SERVICE (NRCS). SINCE THE BAKER PAC HAS SEEN A 75  REDUCTION IN THE NUMBER OF SAGE-GROUSE SINCE 2005, THE BAKER LOCAL IMPLEMENTATION TEAM (LIT) WAS REINVIGORATED AND HAS TAKEN A  ALL HANDS-ON DECK  APPROACH TO HELPING SAGE-GROUSE. TRI-COUNTY, ALONG WITH OTHER PROJECT PARTNERS INCLUDING NRCS, US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE, BLM, BAKER COUNTY WEED CONTROL, OREGON DEPT. OF AG, ODFW, AND PRIVATE LANDOWNERS ARE WORKING TOGETHER TO INCREASE THE QUANTITY AND QUALITY OF SAGE GROUSE HABITAT.
THE MISSION OF THE INSTITUTE FOR APPLIED ECOLOGY (IAE) IS TO CONSERVE NATIVE SPECIES AND HABITATS THROUGH RESTORATION, RESEARCH, AND EDUCATION.
ORWA NOXIOUS VEGETATION MANAGEMENT FOR THE ENHANCEMENT OF BLM LANDS

NOXIOUS WEEDS DISPLACE NATIVE SPECIES, DESTROY NATURAL HABITAT, CLOG WATERWAYS, AND INCREASE EROSION AND FIRE RISK. RESTORATION OF NATIVE PLANT COMMUNITIES AS A RESULT OF NOXIOUS WEED CONTROL WOULD MAINTAIN AND OR ENHANCE AQUATIC AND WILDLIFE HABITATS IN THE LONG-TERM. ADDITIONALLY, MAINTENANCE OR INCREASE IN NATIVE GRASS AND FORB COVER ON TREATMENT AREAS AND ADJACENT AREAS POTENTIALLY INVADED BY UNCONTROLLED WEEDS. IF LEFT UNTREATED, IT WOULD NEGATIVELY IMPACT A NUMBER OF AQUATIC AND WILDLIFE SPECIES THROUGH CONTINUED LOSS OF HABITAT DIVERSITY ON TREATMENT AREAS AND ADJACENT AREAS AS WEEDS CONTINUE TO SPREAD. CONTROLLING NOXIOUS WEEDS WITHIN THE WILD AND SCENIC RIVER CORRIDORS DIRECTLY IMPROVES THE REMARKABLE VALUES FOR WHICH THE DESIGNATIONS WERE AWARDED, AND WILL HELP TO RESTORE OR IMPROVE FOREST, RANGELAND AND WATERSHED HEALTH.
ID TRI-COUNTY NOXIOUS WEED CONTROL
MT DK MISSOULA COUNTY INTEGRATED VEGETATION MANAGEMENT

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO MANAGE INVASIVE AND NOXIOUS WEEDS ON PUBLIC BLM LANDS IN POWDER RIVER COUNTY, MONTANA VENTENATA, SALT CEDAR, LEAFY SPURGE AND CANADA THISTLE ARE THE PRIMARY WEEDS OF CONCERN  HOWEVER, IT IS IMPERATIVE TO CONSTANTLY INVENTORY FOR ANY NEW INVASIVE SPECIES  AREAS OF GREATEST CONCERN ARE WEST MOOREHEAD ROAD, EAST MOOREHEAD ROAD, AND POWDERVILLE ROAD  OBJECTIVE 1  CONTROL INVASIVE SPECIES WITH HERBICIDE  USE OF HERBICIDE AS A WEED MANAGEMENT TOOL SUPPORTS THE MISSION BY PROVIDING AN EFFECTIVE MEANS OF QUICKLY ERADICATING NEW WEED INFESTATIONS AND BY PROVIDING SOME RESIDUAL CONTROL IN MORE ESTABLISHED INFESTATIONS  HERBICIDE WILL BE APPLIED WITHIN APPROVED LABEL RATES, AT TIMELY INTERVALS THROUGHOUT THE GROWING SEASON TO MAINTAIN AND KILL SELECTED WEED INFESTATIONS  APPLICATION RECORDS WILL BE FILLED OUT FOR EACH CHEMICAL APPLICATION AND MAPPING OF THOSE APPLICATIONS WILL BE DONE VIA GPS  THE GOALS OF THIS PROJECT WOULD BE TO KEEP THESE WEEDS INFESTATIONS FROM ENCROACHING ON PRIVATE AND STATE TRUST LANDS BORDERING BLM SECTIONS OBJECTIVE 2  REDUCE SEED SOURCES AND SPREAD OF NOXIOUS WEEDS WITH BIOLOGICAL CONTROL BIOLOGICAL CONTROL CONTRIBUTES TO THE MISSION BY DIVERSIFYING WEED MANAGEMENT TECHNIQUES FOR A MORE INTEGRATED APPROACH TO WEED CONTROL  BIOLOGICAL CONTROL WILL CONTINUE TO BE UTILIZED IN AREAS OF LARGER INFESTATIONS TO THIN OLDER, MORE ESTABLISHED WEED INFESTATIONS

IN GUNNISON COUNTY WE HAVE A GREAT OPPORTUNITY TO PROTECT AND RESTORE THE HABITAT OF THE GUNNISONSAGEGROUSE CENTROCERCUS MINIMUS , A SPECIES OF GROUSE THAT IS FEDERALLY LISTED AS THREATENED  CHEATGRASS BROMUS TECTORUM , IS AN ANNUAL GRASS SPECIES THAT IS ONE OF THE GREATEST THREATS TO GUNNISON SAGE GROUSEHABITAT AND THE SAGE STEPPE  CHEATGRASS IS HIGHLY FLAMMABLE  AND DENSELY GROWING POPULATIONS OF CHEATGRASSPROVIDE AMPLE FINE  TEXTURED FUELS THAT INCREASE FIRE INTENSITY AND OFTEN DECREASE THE INTERVALS BETWEEN FIRES  IFFIRE STRIKES CHEATGRASS INFESTED LAND, NATIVE PLANT COMMUNITIES CAN BE INEXTRICABLY ALTERED  THIS PARTNERSHIP WILLADVOCATE FOR THE INTERGRADED APPROACHES NEEDED TO KEEP CHEATGRASS AT MANAGEABLE LEVELS TO INCREASE PUBLICSAFETY AND TO PROTECT THE ROLLING SAGE STEPPE ECOSYSTEM OF THE GUNNISON BASIN THROUGH MONITORING AND MAPPING, THIS PARTNERSHIP WILL HELP CREATE A MANAGEMENT PLAN FOR DESIGNATED PROBLEMAREAS AND GIVE OPPORTUNITIES FOR ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT  THIS WILL ENSURE THAT RESOURCES FOR CONTROLLINGCHEATGRASS ARE PRIORITIZED THROUGHOUT THE BASIN AND ITS MULTIPLE PUBLIC LAND MANAGEMENT AGENCIES

THE PURPOSE OF THE AWARD IS TO COORDINATE AND CARRY OUT WEED CONTROL AND WEED INVENTORIES ON BLM ADMINISTERED LANDS OR LANDS BENEFITING BLM LANDS NOXIOUS AND INVASIVE WEED CONTROL IN CLOSE COORDINATION WITH BLM  THIS INCLUDED INVENTORY AND MAPPING OF WEEDS IN THE AREA, TREATMENT OF WEEDS IDENTIFIED GIVEN TIME AND FUNDING CONSTRAINTS, AND REPORTING OF ALL TREATMENTS AND MAPPING AT THE BEGINNING OF EACH YEAR S TREATMENTS SEASON, WE WILL COORDINATE WITH BATTLE MOUNTAIN BLM TO DEVELOP AN ANNUAL WORK PLAN AND IDENTIFY PRIORITY INVENTORY AND TREATMENTS FOR THE UPCOMING SEASON  PESTICIDE APPLICATOR RECORDS  PARS  WILL BE COMPLETED FOR EACH TREATMENT PERFORMED  MANUAL TREATMENTS WILL ALSO BE RECORDED  ALL INVENTORIES AND TREATMENTS WILL BE RECORDED WITH GPS  ALL TREATMENT REPORTS AND INVENTORY RECORDS WILL BE REPORTED TO BLM BY THE END OF EACH CALENDAR YEAR

L22AC00539   MT DAK INVASIVE SPECIES CONTROL AND  MANAGEMENT MEADE AND  LAWRENCE COUNTIESINTRODUCTION, PURPOSE, OBJECTIVES AND RELEVANCE A  THE PROJECT IS NEEDED TO ASSIST IN THE CONTROL OF INVASIVE SPECIES IN LAWRENCE AND  MEADE COUNTY  B  THE OBJECTIVE IS TO IDENTIFY AND TREAT INVASIVE SPECIES IN LAWRENCE AND  MEADE COUNTY  C  THE OBJECTIVE SUPPORTS OUR MISSION OF CONTROLLING THE SPREAD OF INVASIVE SPECIES IN LAWRENCE AND  MEADE COUNTY  THE PROJECT WILL BENEFIT THE PUBLIC BY REDUCING THE SPREAD OF INVASIVES ONTO PRIVATE LAND THUS INCREASING THE VALUE OF THE LAND  D  THIS PROJECT WILL PRESERVE CURRENT POSITIONS IN THE MEADE COUNTY WEED AND PEST DEPARTMENT AND WILL REQUIRE THE ADDITION OF ONE NEW SEASONAL POSITION  THIS PROJECT WILL INCREASE THE ECONOMIC VALUE OF THE LAND BY REDUCING THE SPREAD AND NUMBER OF INVASIVE INFESTATIONS  BY REDUCING INVASIVE INFESTATIONS WE WILL ENSURE BIODIVERSITY AND THUS REDUCE FUTURE EXPENSES ON TREATMENTS OF LARGER INFESTATIONS TECHNICAL APPROACHMEADE COUNTY WEED AND PEST WILL WORK IN CONJUNCTION WITH THE BLM TO IDENTIFY INVASIVE INFESTATIONS AND TREATMENT AREAS  TREATMENTS WILL BE MADE BY MEADE COUNTY WEED AND PEST, WHEN INSTRUCTED BY THE BLM, TO ACHIEVE MAXIMUM CONTROL OF INVASIVE INFESTATIONS  A  TREATMENTS WILL BE MADE BY ATV MOUNTED SPRAY EQUIPMENT TO DESIRED AREAS IN MAY OCTOBER  FOLLOW UP TREATMENTS WILL BE DONE AT A LATER TIME IF NEEDED  B  MEADE COUNTY WEED AND PEST WILL RECORD ALL TREATMENTS APPLIED TO INFESTED AREAS AND WILL SHARE THE INFORMATION WITH THE BLM  C  MEADE COUNTY WEED AND PEST EXPECTS TO SUPPRESS THE SPREAD OF INVASIVES BY PREVENTING THE PRODUCTION OF INVASIVE SEED AND MANAGING EXISTING INFESTATIONS  D  MEADE COUNTY WEED AND PEST AND THE BLM WILL INSPECT TREATMENT AREAS AND DISCUSS CHEMICAL EFFICACY TO ENSURE PROJECT GOALS ARE MET  IF DESIRED GOALS ARE NOT MET, MEADE COUNTY WEED AND PEST WILL RETREAT UNAFFECTED AREAS WITHIN PROJECT SCHEDULE QUALIFICATIONS, EXPERIENCE, AND PAST PERFORMANCEMEADE COUNTY WEED AND PEST AND THE BLM WILL IDENTIFY TREATMENT AREAS AND INVASIVES TARGETED FOR THIS PROJECT  MEADE COUNTY WEED AND PEST WILL PERFORM ALL TREATMENTS AS DIRECTED BY THE BLM  MEADE COUNTY WEED AND PEST WILL SELECT THE MOST APPROPRIATE TREATMENT TECHNIQUES FOR INVASIVE INFESTATIONS  ALL MEADE COUNTY APPLICATORS WILL BE CERTIFIED BY THE STATE OF SOUTH DAKOTA  ALL TREATMENTS WILL BE MONITORED BY AN EXPERIENCED MEADE COUNTY WEED AND PEST SUPERVISOR TO ENSURE PROPER RATES AND TREATMENT TECHNIQUES  TREATMENTS WILL COMMENCE WHEN DESIRED PROJECT GOALS ARE MET

THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO CONDUCT COUNTY WEED CONTROL  INVENTORY, TREATMENT, AND MONITORING OF NOXIOUS WEEDS WHICH THREATEN THE HEALTH OF COLORADO S NATURAL LANDSCAPES AND THE VALUES THEY PROVIDE THE PUBLIC  METRICS PRIMARY ACTIONS THAT RECIPIENT INTENDS TO UTILIZE IN CARRYING OUT THE PROPOSED PROJECT, INCLUDES 1 EXECUTE INTEGRATED PEST MANAGEMENT TO ERADICATE NEW POPULATIONS TO PREVENT THEIR SPREAD 2 WHEN ERADICATION IS NOT POSSIBLE, RECIPIENT WILL SEEK TO REDUCE NOXIOUS WEED POPULATIONS AND IMPACTS TOWHERE THEY WILL NOT SIGNIFICANTLY AFFECT LOCAL ECONOMIES OR THE ENVIRONMENT
TO ASSIST MOFFAT COUNTY IN THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE NOXIOUS WEED PLAN, THEREBY SUSTAINING AND IMPROVING COLORADO FIRST CONSERVATION DISTRICT NATURAL RESOURCES

THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO CREATE A COORDINATED RESPONSE TO NOXIOUS AND INVASIVE PLANT SPECIES THROUGHOUT THE SIERRA SOIL AND WATER CONSERVATION DISTRICT AND SIERRA COUNTY IN SOUTHERN NEW MEXICO  THE PROJECT WILL INCLUDE INVENTORYING, MAPPING, AND TREATING AREAS INFESTED WITH STATE LISTED NOXIOUS PLANTS AND MONITORING OF TREATMENT EFFICACY  THE PROJECT ALSO SEEKS TO RAISE PUBLIC AWARENESS OF THE DETRIMENTAL EFFECTS OF NOXIOUS WEEDS AND THE IMPORTANCE OF MANAGING NOXIOUS PLANTS THROUGH COMMUNITY OUTREACH NOXIOUS AND INVASIVE WEEDS IMPACT WILDLIFE HABITAT AND FORAGE, THREATEN RARE AND ENDANGERED SPECIES, ALTER FIRE FREQUENCY, INCREASE EROSION, AND DEPLETE SOIL MOISTURE  WORKING TO ELIMINATE THESE SPECIES WILL BENEFIT PUBLIC AND PRIVATE LAND AS WELL AS THE PEOPLE, PLANTS, AND ANIMALS THAT INHABIT THE AREA INVASIVE SPECIES COST THE PUBLIC MILLIONS OF DOLLARS IN CONTROL AND MANAGEMENT EACH YEAR AND MANY INVASIVE PLANTS AND NOXIOUS WEEDS ARE HIGHLY COMPETITIVE AND HAVE THE ABILITY TO PERMANENTLY DEGRADE OUR PUBLIC LANDS NOXIOUS WEEDS AND INVASIVE SPECIES EXPANSION ARE RECOGNIZED AS THE SINGLE GREATEST THREAT TO NATIVE PLANT COMMUNITIES AND THE VALUES THEY PROVIDE US NATIVE PLANT COMMUNITIES ARE ESSENTIAL FOR SUPPORTING WILDLIFE HABITAT, WATERSHED FUNCTION, RECREATION OPPORTUNITIES, RURAL ECONOMIES AND WORKING LANDSCAPES INVASIVE PLANTS AND NOXIOUS WEEDS AFFECT PLANT AND ANIMAL COMMUNITIES ON FARMS AND RANCHES, AND IN PARKS, WATERS, FORESTS, NATURAL AREAS, AND BACKYARDS IN NEGATIVE WAYS HUMAN ACTIVITY SUCH AS TRADE, TRAVEL, AND TOURISM HAVE ALL INCREASED SUBSTANTIALLY, ESCALATING THE SPEED AND VOLUME OF SPECIES MOVEMENT TO UNPRECEDENTED LEVELS INCREASED SITE VULNERABILITY FROM WILDFIRES THAT ARE MORE FREQUENT AND OTHER DISTURBANCES IS AN ONGOING CHALLENGE TO MAINTAINING THE INTEGRITY OF OUR NATIVE PLANT COMMUNITIES NOXIOUS WEEDS ARE PARTICULARLY AGGRESSIVE PLANTS LEGALLY DESIGNATED BY STATES AS BEING INJURIOUS TO PUBLIC HEALTH, THE ENVIRONMENT OR THE ECONOMY INVASIVE SPECIES AND NOXIOUS WEEDS ADVERSELY AFFECT OVERALL RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES ON PUBLIC LAND I E , HUNTING, FISHING, CAMPING, HIKING, WATERSHED HEALTH AND ECOSYSTEM FUNCTION WHICH RESULT IN ECONOMIC LOSSES IN RURAL AND URBAN COMMUNITIES AFFECT ADJACENT PRIVATE LANDS, BOTH RURAL AND URBAN, CAUSING WIDESPREAD ECONOMIC LOSSES TO THE AGRICULTURAL INDUSTRY AS WELL AS TO OTHER RESOURCES GOALSINVENTORY AND MAPPING OF INVASIVE AND NOXIOUS PLANT SPECIES THROUGHOUT THE DISTRICT AND SIERRA COUNTY TREATMENT OF INVASIVE AND NOXIOUS PLANT SPECIES THROUGHOUT THE DISTRICT AND COUNTYMONITORING TREATMENT EFFICACYDISTRICT INTERACTIVE MAP UPDATESEDUCATION OF INTERESTED STAKEHOLDERS ON NOXIOUS AND INVASIVE PLANT SPECIES
IMPROVE RANGELAND HEALTH BY TREATING INVASIVE AND NOXIOUS WEEDS ONMULTIPLE OWNERSHIPS

DESIGNATED WATERSHED AREA  COUNTY WIDE  YELLOWSTONE COUNTY, MONTANA PROJECT ABSTRACT  THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS FOR NOXIOUS WEED CONTROL ON BLM PROPERTIES IN YELLOWSTONE COUNTY  THE NEED FOR NOXIOUS WEED CONTROL ON FEDERAL LAND AND SURROUNDING FEDERAL LAND IS CRITICAL TO THE FUTURE SUSTAINABILITY AND ECOLOGICAL HEALTH OF THE OVERALL ECOSYSTEM  NOXIOUS WEEDS ARE DEVASTATING TO THE LANDSCAPE, WILDLIFE, NATIVE VEGETATION, AND AGRICULTURE PRACTICES, SO IT SO NECESSARY TO CONTINUE MANAGEMENT EFFORTS IN THESE AREAS  COMPLY WITH CURRENT FEDERAL AND MONTANA STATE PESTICIDE LAWS AND REGULATIONS  THE FEDERAL INSECTICIDE, FUNGICIDE, AND RODENTICIDE ACT OF 1972, AS AMENDED, P L  92 516 REQUIRES THAT ALL PERSONNEL APPLYING RESTRICTED USE PESTICIDES ARE CERTIFIED IN THE USE OF THESE PESTICIDES OR UNDER THE DIRECT SUPERVISION OF CERTIFIED APPLICATORS  ADDITIONALLY, IT WILL BE THE POLICY OF THE BLM THAT ALL NON RESTRICTED PESTICIDES SHALL BE APPLIED BY CERTIFIED APPLICATORS OR UNDER THE DIRECT SUPERVISION OF A CERTIFIED APPLICATOR  COMPLY WITH CURRENT FEDERAL AND MONTANA STATE PESTICIDE LAWS AND REGULATIONS  THE FEDERAL INSECTICIDE, FUNGICIDE, AND RODENTICIDE ACT OF 1972, AS AMENDED, P L  92 516 REQUIRES THAT ALL PERSONNEL APPLYING RESTRICTED USE PESTICIDES ARE CERTIFIED IN THE USE OF THESE PESTICIDES OR UNDER THE DIRECT SUPERVISION OF CERTIFIED APPLICATORS  ADDITIONALLY, IT WILL BE THE POLICY OF THE BLM THAT ALL NON RESTRICTED PESTICIDES SHALL BE APPLIED BY CERTIFIED APPLICATORS OR UNDER THE DIRECT SUPERVISION OF A CERTIFIED APPLICATOR STATEMENT OF NEED  TO CONTROL NEW AND EXISTING COUNTY LISTED AND STATE LISTED NOXIOUS WEEDS TECHNICAL APPROACH  ALL PERSONNEL INVOLVED IN PLANNING, REVIEWING, SUPERVISING, OR APPLYING PESTICIDES ARE ADEQUATELY TRAINED TO HANDLE PESTICIDES AND EQUIPMENT PROPERLY  THIS ENSURES THAT CONTROL MEASURES ARE APPLIED WITH MAXIMUM SAFETY, EFFICIENCY, AND ECONOMY  CONTINUED TRAINING, PERIODIC EXAMINATIONS AND APPROPRIATE CERTIFICATION OF PERSONNEL ARE REQUIRED TO SAFEGUARD AGAINST MISUSE, PREVENT CONTAMINATION OF THE ENVIRONMENT, AND PROTECT PUBLIC LANDS  PROVIDE COPIES OF PESTICIDE APPLICATION RECORDS  PAR  FOR EACH APPLICATION SITE RECORDING THE DATE OF APPLICATION, START TIME, FINISH TIME, AMOUNT OF HERBICIDE, SURFACTANT AND DYE APPLIED, AND ACRES TREATED  MEET WITH THE BILLINGS FIELD OFFICE WEED COORDINATOR PRIOR TO BEGINNING ANY WORK, TO DECIDE ON METHOD OF APPLICATION, TYPE OF HERBICIDE, AND RATE TO BE USED, TIMING OF APPLICATION, TARGET SPECIES, AND OBJECTIVE OF TREATMENT PROJECT MONITORING AND EVALUTION PLANBLM LANDS THAT ARE CURRENTLY MONITORED WILL CONTINUE TO BE MONITORED AND TREATED ON A YEARLY BASIS THROUGHOUT THE GROWING SEASON EACH YEAR  ALL AREAS WILL BE EVALUATED FOR PRIORITY AND TREATMENT OPTIONS DEPENDING ON SPECIES OF NOXIOUS WEEDS THAT ARE PRESENT
MT DAK NOXIOUS WEED CONTROL SWEET GRASS COUNTY

STATEMENT OF NEED  THERE HAS BEEN AN EXPLOSIVE GROWTH OF SPOTTED KNAPWEED AND LEAFY SPURGE ON THE BURNED ACRES OF CARBON COUNTY S BLM PROPERTY  DUE TO THE LARGE NUMBER OF NEW ACREAGE INFESTED, IT IS IMPERATIVE AN INTEGRATED WEED MANAGEMENT PLAN IS PUT IN PLACE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES  IT IS CARBON COUNTY S GOAL TO USE BLM FUNDS TO GAIN CONTROL OVER THE NEW INFESTATIONS  THIS WILL TAKE SEVERAL YEARS PUBLIC AND PROGRAM INTEREST OF THE BLM  CARBON COUNTY WEED DISTRICT WILL USE MEDIA AND IN HOUSE EDUCATION TO ENSURE THE PUBLIC IS AWARE OF THIS PROGRAM  THERE MAY BE ACTIVITIES, SUCH AS WEED PULLS, THOSE WITH INTEREST CAN VOLUNTEER TO PARTICIPATE IN ACTIVITIES  MANY EDUCATIONAL ACTIVITIES WILL BE AVAILABLE THROUGHOUT THE YEARS OF THIS PROJECT  HUNTER S SAFETY HAS ADDED A NOXIOUS WEED COMPONENT TO THEIR PROGRAM  ALONG WITH THAT THERE WILL EDUCATION IN OUR TOWNS AS WELL AS SMALL ACREAGE WORKSHOPS AVAILABLE TO ALL WHO WISH TO ATTEND METHODS  TRUCK, UTV, BACKPACK SPRAYING AS WELL AS HELICOPTER SPRAYING WILL BE USED AS THE METHODS OF APPLICATION TIMETABLE OR MILESTONES  BECAUSE OF THE LARGE EXTENT OF THIS NEW INFESTATION, THIS PROJECT WILL TAKE 5 YEARS  THE FIRST 3 YEARS A MEASURE OF CONTROL SHOULD BE ABLE TO BE SEEN  THE FOLLOWING 2 YEARS WILL BE USED FOR CLEAN UP AND CONTINUED CONTROL MEASURES INFORMATION TO SUPPORT ENVIRONMENTAL COMPLIANCE REVIEW REQUIREMENTS   NOTE  PROJECTS UNDER WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT, THE NATIVE PLANT PROGRAM, THREATENED AND ENDANGERED SPECIES HABITAT CONSERVATION   THE NARRATIVE SHOULD PROVIDE ENOUGH DETAIL SO THAT REVIEWERS ARE ABLE TO DETERMINE PROJECT COMPLIANCE WITH SECTION 7 OF THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT OF 1973   N ADESCRIPTION OF STAKEHOLDER COORDINATION OR INVOLVEMENT  REGULAR SITE VISITS WILL BE GIVEN AS WELL AS REGULAR EMAILS AND PHONE CALLS  THERE IS GOOD COMMUNICATION BETWEEN CARBON COUNTY WEED DISTRICT AND BLM REQUIRED PROJECT MONITORING AND EVALUATION PLAN, INCLUDING HOW YOU WILL MEASURE PROJECT PERFORMANCE AND ASSESSMENT TOOLS TO BE USED  PHOTO POINTS AS WELL AS MAPS WILL BEGIN THIS PROJECT  AS IT UNFOLDS, CONTINUED PHOTO POINTS AND MAPS WILL BE USED TO MEASURE THE SUCCESS OF THIS PROJECT INFORMATION ON KEY PROJECT PERSONNEL  THE SUPERVISOR OF THIS PROJECT HAS BEEN WITH THE COUNTY WEED DISTRICT FOR OVER 18 YEARS  DURING THOSE YEARS, HE HAS BEEN THE SOLE PROJECT SUPERVISOR  OVER THE LAST FEW YEARS HAS BEEN THE KEY PERSONNEL AS WELL ANTICIPATED FUTURE FUNDING NEEDS  NOXIOUS WEEDS WILL ALWAYS BE AROUND  TO BE A GOOD STEWARD, ONE MUST BE VIGILANT IN OBSERVATION AND PRACTICE OF WEED CONTROL  LEAFY SPURGE WILL CONTINUE TO BE AN ISSUE ON THESE ACRES AND WILL NEED CONTINUAL OBSERVATION AND CONTROL DETAILS AND SUPPORTING DOCUMENTATION ON THE PROJECT LOCATION  ALL BLM PROPERTIES IN CARBON COUNTY OTHER PROGRAM OR PROJECT SPECIFIC NARRATIVE REQUIREMENTS  NONE

THE PRIMARY PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS TO SUPPORT THE MISSOULA COUNTY WEED DISTRICT S EFFORTS TO COORDINATE BIOCONTROL EFFORTS IN THE STATE OF MONTANA PRIMARILY BY HOUSING AND STAFFING THE MONTANA BIOCONTROL COORDINATION PROJECT  MTBCP   MTBCP IS A GRASSROOTS EFFORT INITIATED IN 2013 BY FEDERAL, STATE, COUNTY, NON PROFIT, AND PRIVATE LAND MANAGERS THROUGHOUT MONTANA WHO SAW A NEED FOR INCREASED COORDINATION WITHIN THE STATE S WEED BIOCONTROL PROGRAM  MTBCP STRIVES TO PROVIDE THE LEADERSHIP, COORDINATION, AND EDUCATION THAT WILL ENABLE LAND MANAGERS IN THE STATE OF MONTANA TO SUCCESSFULLY INCORPORATE BIOLOGICAL WEED CONTROL AS PART OF THEIR NOXIOUS WEED MANAGEMENT PROGRAM  THIS IS ACCOMPLISHED BY FOCUSING ON COLLECTING AND DISTRIBUTING INSECTS, TRACKING RELEASE SITES FOR POTENTIAL FUTURE COLLECTION SITES, MONITORING TO DETERMINE IMPACTS OF BIOCONTROL, PROVIDING EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS, SUPPORTING BIOCONTROL RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT, COORDINATING WITH OUT OF STATE PARTNERS, SUPPORTING BIOCONTROL CONSORTIUMS, AND CONDUCTING SURVEYS FOR PARTNER NEEDS THE ANNUAL DELIVERABLES OF THE MTBCP ARE DISTRIBUTION OF BIOLOGICAL WEED CONTROL AGENTS TO ALL IN STATE AND OUT OF STATE PARTNERS IN NEED COMPILING ALL BIOCONTROL AGENT RELEASE SITE LOCATIONS WITHIN MONTANA TO BE STORED IN A DATABASE AND CREATE AN ASSOCIATED MAP MONITOR APPROXIMATELY 100 BIOCONTROL RELEASE SITES FOR CHANGES IN VEGETATION DUE TO BIOLOGICAL WEED CONTROL PROVIDE APPROXIMATELY 12 EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS ON BIOLOGICAL WEED CONTROL TO AND FOR LAND MANAGERS THROUGHOUT MONTANA THIS PROJECT PROVIDES BENEFITS TO BOTH PRIVATE AND PUBLIC LAND MANAGERS  EDUCATIONAL WORKSHOPS AND FIELD DAYS ARE OPEN TO BOTH PUBLIC AND PRIVATE LAND MANAGERS TO ATTEND  AT THESE EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS, WE DISCUSS TOPICS INCLUDING MISCONCEPTIONS OF BIOCONTROL, PROPER USE OF BIOCONTROL, COLLECTION, RELEASE AND MONITORING TECHNIQUES, RESEARCH UPDATES, ETC  ADDITIONALLY, ANYWHERE BETWEEN 1 AND 2 MILLION BIOCONTROL AGENTS ARE DISTRIBUTED ANNUALLY BECAUSE OF THIS PROJECT  THESE AGENTS ARE RELEASED ON BOTH PRIVATE AND PUBLIC LAND  OFTEN THESE AGENTS WILL DISPERSE ON THEIR OWN AND POTENTIALLY TO NEARBY WEED INFESTATIONS, LEADING TO BENEFITS IN FUTURE YEARS

LIBERTY COUNTY, TOOLE COUNTY AND THE BLM WILL WORK TOGETHER WITH PRIVATE AND NON FEDERAL LANDOWNERS TO PREVENT, CONTAIN AND CONTROL THE SPREAD OF NOXIOUS WEEDS IN THE MARIAS RIVER WATERSHED AND THE SWEET GRASS HILLS OF TOOLE AND LIBERTY COUNTIES  BECAUSE THESE PLANTS MOVE RAPIDLY FROM ONE OWNER S LAND TO ANOTHER, JOINT EFFORTS TO ERADICATE, CONTAIN OR CONTROL NOXIOUS WEEDS WILL REDUCE ADVERSE IMPACTS ON PUBLIC AND PRIVATE LANDS AND REDUCE COSTS TO BOTH BLM AND OTHER LANDOWNERS BECAUSE THESE COUNTIES DO NOT HAVE THE FUNDS TO WORK ON THE PUBLIC LANDS AND THE BLM DOESN T HAVE THE AUTHORITY TO WORK ON PRIVATE LANDS, THE COUNTIES WILL PROVIDE THE SERVICES ON ALL THE LANDS AND REQUEST REIMBURSEMENT FOR THEIR EXPENSES FOR SERVICES PERFORMED AND SUPPLIES USED THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ADDRESS SPOTTED KNAPWEED, RUSSIAN KNAPWEED, LEAFY SPURGE, HOUNDS TONGUE, CANADA THISTLE AND PERENNIAL PEPPERWEED INFESTATIONS ACROSS ADMINISTRATIVE BOUNDARIES  THIS PROJECT WILL ALSO ASSIST WITH THE TREATMENT AND REMOVAL OF RUSSIAN OLIVE TREES ALONG THE MARIAS RIVER BELOW TIBER DAM THE ABILITY TO WORK ACROSS OWNERSHIPS ALLOWS FOR HOLISTIC MANAGEMENT OF THE ENTIRE PROBLEM  IN THIS WAY ALL PARTNERS ENSURE THAT WEED ISSUES ARE NOT ALLOWED TO PERSIST OVER TIME AND CONTRIBUTE TO NEW INFESTATIONS ON ALL OWNERSHIPS  DUE TO THE ISOLATED NATURE OF THE CURRENT INFESTATIONS, THE AREA HAS BEEN DESIGNATED BY THE COUNTY AS PART OF A COOPERATIVE WEED PREVENTION AREA IN THE SWEET GRASS HILLS, AND A COOPERATIVE WEED MANAGEMENT AREA ALONG THE MARIAS RIVER  THESE EFFORTS HELP TO PROTECT PUBLIC LANDS IN THE AREA WHICH ALSO INCLUDES AN AREA OF CRITICAL ENVIRONMENTAL CONCERN  ACEC

THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO QUANTIFY THE COMBINED EFFECTS OF HERBICIDE  IMAZAPIC  AND FALL  SEPT   OCT  TARGETED GRAZING BY CATTLE ON THE QUANTITY OF THATCH, SOIL MICROCLIMATE, AND SEED BANK DYNAMICS OF A WINTER ANNUAL DOMINATED GRAZING ALLOTMENT IN THE KLAMATH FALLS RESOURCE AREA

SWEETWATER COUNTY WEED AND PEST CONTROL DISTRICT IS PLEASED TO BE CONSIDERED FOR THE COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT WITH THE BLM OF THE CONTROL OF INVASIVE AND NOXIOUS WEEDS THROUGHOUT SWEETWATER COUNTY. OUR GOAL IS AS FOLLOWS:TO LOCATE AND MAP AREAS OF CONCERN ACROSS RANGELANDS AND WATER SHED AREAS THAT INFESTED WITH NOXIOUS WEEDS. ORGANIZE A WEED MANAGEMENT PLAN FOR AREA THAT SUPPORTS THE BLM'S GOALS FOR IMPROVING AND BUILDING HEALTHY ECOSYSTEMS WITHIN SWEETWATER COUNTY. TREAT INFESTED AREAS BASED ON APPROVED IPM STANDARDS AND PRACTICES. HERBICIDE TREATMENTS WILL BE MADE TO SELECTED SITE SPECIFIC AREAS UNDER THE DIRECTION OF WEED MANAGERS. WE WILL BE USING A VARIETY OF APPLICATION METHODS INCLUDING SIDE-BY-SIDE SPRAYERS, BACKPACK SPRAYERS AND HORSE PACK SPRAYERS. HERBICIDES WILL BE APPLIED IN ACCORDANCE WITH LEGAL LABELING DIRECTIONS BY COMMERCIAL PESTICIDE APPLICATORS. EACH APPLICATION WILL BE MADE WITH CONSIDERATION TO THOSE DESIRING TO USE AND ENJOY PUBLIC LANDS. HERBICIDE APPLICATION WILL BE MAPPED USING SPRAY LOGGER TECHNOLOGY AND APPROPRIATE RECORDS WILL BE KEPT FOR FUTURE REFERENCE.WE ARE PLEASE TO PARTNER WITH THE BLM ON THIS LARGE LANDSCAPE PROJECT IN PROTECTING OUR LAND AND RESOURCES FROM THE THREAT AND INVASION OF NOXIOUS WEEDS.

MUCH OF BLM LANDS IN TETON COUNTY, WYOMING ARE LOCATED ALONG THE SNAKE RIVER. NOXIOUS WEED CONTROL OF ALL STATE OF  WYOMING DESIGNATED AND TETON COUNTY DECLARED SPECIES WILL OCCUR DURING THE SUMMER OF 2022 ON BLM LANDS WITHIN  TETON COUNTY, WYOMING. TETON COUNTY WEED AND PEST DISTRICT CREWS WILL TREAT, MONITOR AND MAP INFESTATIONS IN THESE  AREAS. BLM FUNDS WILL BE USED TO TREAT BLM LANDS. ADDITIONAL NOXIOUS WEED TREATMENTS WILL BE ONGOING ON LANDS  ADJACENT TO BLM, INCLUDING THE SNAKE RIVER LEVEE SYSTEM, THROUGH FUNDING AND PARTNERSHIPS AMONG ALL MEMBERS OF THE  JACKSON HOLE WEED MANAGEMENT ASSOCIATION. BLM IS A LONGSTANDING PARTNER IN THIS COOPERATIVE WEED MANAGEMENT  AREA AND THE JHWMA APPRECIATES THE CONTINUED SUPPORT. THE JHWMA WAS ESTABLISHED IN 1998. OUR SNAKE RIVER EDRR (EARLY DETECTION RAPID RESPONSE) PROJECT HAS BEEN INSTRUMENTAL IN KEEPING NEW INVADERS SUCH AS  PERENNIAL PEPPERWEED, SALTCEDAR AND RUSSIAN OLIVE FROM ESTABLISHING ON THE SNAKE RIVER SYSTEM. WITH THIS LEVEL OF  SUPPORT, WE HOPE TO UTILIZE A PORTION OF BLM FUNDS TO COMPLIMENT THIS LABOR-INTENSIVE EFFORT. OVER THE YEARS, WE HAVE  HAD STRONG SUPPORT FOR EDRR TREATMENTS, BIOLOGICAL CONTROL AND REVEGETATION PROJECTS ON THE RIVER SYSTEM FROM OUR  JHWMA PARTNERS, ESPECIALLY TETON CONSERVATION DISTRICT, STATE AND PRIVATE FORESTRY GRANTS, GRAND TETON NATIONAL PARK,  WYOMING GAME & FISH DEPARTMENT (SOUTH PARK HABITAT MANAGEMENT AREA) AND THE BRIDGER TETON NATIONAL FOREST. IN  2020 WE DEPLOYED THE WORKING DOGS FOR CONSERVATION AS PART OF THE EDRR PROGRAM WITH GREAT SUCCESS AND WILL BE DOING  SO AGAIN ON ANOTHER STRETCH OF RIVER
IMPLEMENT AN INTEGRATED WEED MANAGEMENT SYSTEM, IN DIRECT COORDINATION WITH BLM, TO CONTAIN, CONTROL, AND PROVIDE EDUCATION/OUTREACH REGARDING UNDESIRABLE PLANT SPECIES.

WSDA WILL WORK IN PARTNERSHIP WITH BLM TO IDENTIFY PRIORITY PROJECTS THAT MAY INCLUDE PREVENTION, EARLY DETECTION, RAPID RESPONSE (EDRR), EDUCATION AND OUTREACH, INTEGRATED WEED CONTROL INCLUDING PHYSICAL, MECHANICAL, CULTURAL OR CHEMICAL CONTROL, COLLECTION AND DISTRIBUTION OF BIOLOGICAL CONTROL AGENTS, AND REPLANTING SITES WHEN FEASIBLE AND NECESSARY.
